etymology.description: Ideogrammic compound: 臣 (“eye pointing down”) + 人 (“person”).
etymology.interpretation: Combines a downward-looking eye with a person to picture someone in a reclining posture. The imagery evokes closed or lowered eyes over a person at rest, hence the sense of lying down.
etymology.simplification: Top component 臣 was streamlined in the simplified form 卧 to reduce strokes while preserving the overall posture-with-person idea; 人 below was retained.

examples.chinese: 他因病卧床(他因病臥床)。
examples.english: He is bedridden due to illness.

examples.chinese: 请你卧倒(請你臥倒)，医生要检查(醫生要檢查)。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng nǐ wòdǎo, yīshēng yào jiǎnchá.
examples.english: Please lie down; the doctor needs to examine you.

examples.chinese: 猫喜欢侧卧在阳光下(貓喜歡側臥在陽光下)。
examples.pinyin: Māo xǐhuān cèwò zài yángguāng xià.
examples.english: The cat likes to lie on its side in the sun.
